Yes, if the text is short, actually lettering it is the best thing. If you are not a letterer, getting a great letterer like Mark Simonson might be the best route, if the publisher can afford it. An actual child's writing might be too undisciplined for readability, but you could try it, as Po-Hsuan suggests.
Take P22's advice, if you want a handwritten font, then hand write it. No digital face can express what the hand can do. Script fonts look fake in my eyes.

i agree.. digital handwritten fonts never look quite right. probably because as each character is repeated, it is the exact same glyph, unlike what happnens when something is actually hand written.   
   
on a side note.. does anybody know if there are any, or if it is possible to make a font where you have several (maybe 5 or so) glyphs for each character that are used at random when typing? I always thought this would be something that would help a handwritten digital face look more authentic.

\> probably because as each character is repeated   
   
I've come to the tentative conclusion that the necessity for letterform "randomness" is limited to foveation. What I mean is that as long as the font uses 3 or 4 variants of a glyph (which is the most we can see in the fovea at one time, and that's assuming 3 or 4 of the same letter ever actually happens in sequence...) it's OK, because short-term memory concerning exact glyph shapes probably doesn't survive a saccade. Interestingly, Letterror's FF Kosmik-Flipper uses 3 variants per character.   
   
But I've also come to realize there's a much bigger problem: handwritten stuff typically has _mistakes_ in it, which can either be corrected -but visibly- or just left in. This means you need some fancy software to replicate that in order for something to truly appear handwritten...
